cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: What is the best lane position for a motorcycle operator?
questions.answerA: The left position in the lane
questions.answerB: The center position in the lane
questions.answerC: The right position in the lane
questions.answerD: There is no single lane position that is best for all situations.
questions.explanation: There is no lane position that is always best and no lane position that should always be avoided. Select a lane position that is appropriate for your current riding conditions, allowing you to maintain an adequate space cushion and be visible to others.

questions.question: The front brake supplies how much of a motorcycle's stopping power?
questions.answerA: About one-quarter
questions.answerB: About one-half
questions.answerC: About three-quarters
questions.answerD: All the stopping power
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide three-fourths of the bike's total stopping power.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger, a motorcyclist should tell the passenger to:
questions.answerA: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerB: Hold onto the seat.
questions.answerC: Put their feet on the muffler.
questions.answerD: Mount the motorcycle after the motorcycle has been started.
questions.explanation: Even if your passenger is also a motorcyclist, you should give them complete safety instructions before leaving on a trip. Ask them to get on the motorcycle only after you have started the engine. They should sit as far forward as possible without crowding you and firmly hold onto your waist, hips, or belt. They should keep both feet on the footrests at all times, even when the bike is stopped.

questions.question: The effects of marijuana consumption can last for:
questions.answerA: No more than 15 minutes.
questions.answerB: About an hour.
questions.answerC: About two hours.
questions.answerD: More than six hours.
questions.explanation: When marijuana is smoked, it can begin to affect the smoker within minutes and effects can last for between two and four hours. When marijuana is eaten, it may take over an hour to begin to affect the consumer, but the effects of the marijuana may last for more than six hours.

questions.question: If you are riding in traffic when a small animal enters your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Do whatever you can, including swerving into other lanes, to avoid hitting the animal.
questions.answerB: Switch lanes as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane.
questions.answerD: Flash your lights to try to scare the animal.
questions.explanation: Do everything you safely can to avoid hitting an animal in the road. If you are in traffic, however, you should remain in your lane. Swerving into another lane of traffic to avoid hitting an animal can cause you to collide with another driver. Hitting something small is less dangerous than hitting something big.

questions.question: If your motorcycle has convex mirrors and you are not familiar with this type of mirror, you should practice using the mirrors because:
questions.answerA: Most people aren’t used to using mirrors.
questions.answerB: Unlike flat mirrors, they make items look farther away than they really are.
questions.answerC: Unlike flat mirrors, they make items look closer than they really are.
questions.answerD: It can be difficult to remember to look at mirrors while riding.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. Take the time to get used to your mirrors if your motorcycle is equipped with convex mirrors.

questions.question: In hot weather, wearing a riding jacket:
questions.answerA: Can help protect against heat exhaustion and dehydration.
questions.answerB: Is discouraged because it can cause heat-related problems.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the jacket is a light color.
questions.answerD: Is not important.
questions.explanation: A riding jacket and long pants should still be worn when riding in hot weather. In addition to their other safety benefits, they can protect a rider from heat exhaustion and dehydration.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signals to indicate that you plan to change lanes.
questions.answerB: Tailgate other drivers.
questions.answerC: Keep your eyes focused no more than 15 feet in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Not use a headlight during the day.
questions.explanation: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should make yourself visible, communicate your intentions to others, maintain adequate space cushions, search your path of travel at least 12 seconds ahead, identify and separate hazards, and be prepared to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: The gear shift lever is located:
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest.
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest.
questions.answerC: Behind the left footrest.
questions.answerD: Behind the right footrest.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the left foot. To shift up to a higher gear, position your foot under the shift lever and lift. To downshift, press the shift lever down.

questions.question: Which of the following surfaces does not provide poor traction?
questions.answerA: Wet pavement
questions.answerB: Dry pavement
questions.answerC: Lane markings
questions.answerD: Snow
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; and painted lane markings can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: A motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerA: Cannot tip over.
questions.answerB: Can tip over if making a turn too fast.
questions.answerC: Is designed to take corners at any speed.
questions.answerD: Should not be used for loading items.
questions.explanation: Even with three wheels on the ground, a sidecar can tip over if it is being turned too sharply or is moving too fast for a corner.

questions.question: Which of the following should you inspect during a pre-ride check?
questions.answerA: The general wear and tread of your tires
questions.answerB: The amount of cushion your seat has
questions.answerC: The shine of your paint
questions.answerD: The wind direction
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: Riding with a passenger:
questions.answerA: Usually results in no difference in handling a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Is usually safe for beginning riders.
questions.answerC: Can affect the handling of a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Is encouraged to get operators used to different riding situations.
questions.explanation: A passenger puts extra weight on a motorcycle, which causes the motorcycle to handle differently. Only experienced riders should carry passengers.

questions.question: When checking tire pressure:
questions.answerA: Eyeballing the tire is a good method.
questions.answerB: Use a tire gauge.
questions.answerC: It is best to squeeze the tire.
questions.answerD: Compare the height of the tire to another tire.
questions.explanation: You should use a tire gauge to check the tire pressure before every ride. An under-inflated tire may still look okay, so a visual check is not enough.

questions.question: A helmeted rider is _______ more likely to survive a crash than a rider not wearing a helmet.
questions.answerA: Two times
questions.answerB: Three times
questions.answerC: Six times
questions.answerD: 20 times
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: How can you discourage another vehicle from sharing your lane?
questions.answerA: Ride in the middle of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Swerve from side to side in your lane.
questions.explanation: To discourage automobile drivers from trying to share your lane, ride in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Common drugs, such as cold tablets:
questions.answerA: Can affect a rider's abilities to safely operate their motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Usually won’t affect a rider's abilities to safely operate their motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Pose no risk to a rider's operating abilities.
questions.answerD: Are always acceptable to take before riding because they are sold over-the-counter.
questions.explanation: Almost all drugs, including over-the-counter medications, have the potential to impact the abilities you need to ride safely. Make sure you understand the side effects of any drug before combining it with riding.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Provides less than half of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerB: Provides about 70 percent of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Should not be used unless the roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: Should be the only brake you use.
questions.explanation: The front brake is much more powerful than the rear one and provides at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power. Use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: If you are riding and your motorcycle starts to handle differently, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue riding normally.
questions.answerB: Pull over and check the tires.
questions.answerC: Pull over to check the chain.
questions.answerD: Pull over to check the windshield.
questions.explanation: A sudden change in handling may indicate that a tire on your motorcycle has failed. If you feel a change in the way your motorcycle handles, pull over safely and check your tires.

questions.question: When braking, you should use:
questions.answerA: The front brake only.
questions.answerB: The rear brake only.
questions.answerC: Both front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Either the front or rear brake, but not both.
questions.explanation: You should always use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: If you must ride over an obstacle, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your speed as much as possible.
questions.answerB: Lean the motorcycle to one side.
questions.answerC: Speed up, if possible.
questions.answerD: Stay on your seat and remove your feet from the footrests.
questions.explanation: If you are unable avoid an obstacle and must instead ride over it, slow down and approach the obstacle at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Keep your motorcycle straight up and down, if possible. Just before contact, roll off the throttle slightly to lighten the front end of the motorcycle.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should be done:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: To prevent any dangerous situations caused by technical issues, you should perform a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. Compared to a car, small technical problems can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Use your high beam.
questions.answerB: Use the headlights of vehicles ahead to help you see.
questions.answerC: Be visible.
questions.answerD: Ride only in the left portion of your lane.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, use your high beam (unless you are following or meeting another car), take advantage of the headlights of other vehicles, and wear reflective materials to increase your visibility. You should always be flexible about your lane position, selecting whichever position will help you to see, be seen, and have an adequate space cushion.

questions.question: If braking in a curve:
questions.answerA: Only use the front brake.
questions.answerB: It will be the same as braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: You will have more traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.answerD: You may have less traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.explanation: It is possible to use both brakes while turning, but it must be done with great care. Some of the tires' usual traction is being used to make the turn while the motorcycle is leaning, so less traction is available for stopping.

questions.question: Your lane position should not:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerB: Help you avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerC: Provide you with an escape route.
questions.answerD: Welcome other drivers into your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position can optimize a number of safety factors. Your lane position should keep you out of other vehicles’ blind spots, increase your ability to see and be seen, help you avoid surface hazards, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and provide you with an escape route from any hazards that might arise. You should be positioned in a way that discourages other drivers from trying to share your lane.

questions.question: To best control a motorcycle, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Sit with their arms fully extended.
questions.answerB: Use their arms to hold their body up.
questions.answerC: Keep their knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Keep their feet firmly on the footrests.
questions.explanation: When riding, sit so that you can use your arms to control the motorcycle rather than to hold yourself up. Your arms should be slightly bent when you hold the handgrips. To help maintain your balance, keep your knees against the gas tank and your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep going and hope to wake up.
questions.answerB: Ride faster.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Get off the road and rest.
questions.explanation: You should avoid riding if you are tired. When making a long trip, take rest breaks at least every two hours to reduce the risk of becoming fatigued.

questions.question: If operating a three-wheeled motorcycle or riding with a sidecar, do not ride too far to the right of your lane because:
questions.answerA: Other drivers may not see you.
questions.answerB: You will not be able to pass other vehicles as easily.
questions.answerC: Other drivers may try to share your lane.
questions.answerD: You may run off the road.
questions.explanation: Because a sidecar sits on the right side of a motorcycle, riding too far to the right side of your lane risks the sidecar running off the road. Similarly, on a three-wheeled motorcycle, the rear right wheel may leave the road if you get too close to the right edge.

questions.question: If it is warm outside, should you wear a leather jacket while riding?
questions.answerA: No, it will make you too hot.
questions.answerB: Yes, but take frequent breaks to remove the jacket and cool off.
questions.answerC: Yes, riding jackets are made to keep the rider cool, even in warm weather.
questions.answerD: No, jackets get in the way of steering.
questions.explanation: In warm weather, a riding jacket will help prevent dehydration in addition to serving the basic protective function that it provides at all times. Many jackets are designed to protect riders against overheating, even in warm weather.

questions.question: When consumed together, the effects of alcohol and drugs:
questions.answerA: Can be more pronounced than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerB: Are less dangerous than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerC: Are usually minimal.
questions.answerD: Often balance out.
questions.explanation: Many drugs, including prescription and over-the-counter medications, can impair your ability to ride safely. Some medications become even more dangerous when combined with alcohol.

questions.question: In which of the following situations should you increase your following distance?
questions.answerA: Traffic is light.
questions.answerB: Traffic is heavy.
questions.answerC: You are able to see the roadway through vehicles in front of you.
questions.answerD: There is pleasant and clear weather.
questions.explanation: While a two-second following distance is generally adequate, you should increase your following distance any time conditions would require a longer stopping distance, such as when the pavement is slippery due to poor weather conditions. Additionally, you should increase your following distance at night, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead, and when traffic is heavy.

questions.question: Before mounting a motorcycle, you should check all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The air pressure in the tires.
questions.answerB: Fluid levels.
questions.answerC: The turn signals.
questions.answerD: Damage to the paint.
questions.explanation: Before getting on a motorcycle, you should check the tread and air pressure of the tires, the oil and fluid levels, the lights, and the signals.

questions.question: Which of the following provides the best protection?
questions.answerA: Sunglasses
questions.answerB: Windshield
questions.answerC: Goggles
questions.answerD: Face shield
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield provides protection for the wearer's entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles may protect someone's eyes, but not the rest of their face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: The best way to stop quickly is to:
questions.answerA: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerB: Use the rear brake first.
questions.answerC: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes simultaneously.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time. Apply the brakes firmly and do not panic if the brakes lock.

questions.question: Shifting into a lower gear causes an effect similar to:
questions.answerA: Using the brakes.
questions.answerB: Accelerating.
questions.answerC: Swerving.
questions.answerD: Turning.
questions.explanation: Shifting your motorcycle into a lower gear causes an effect similar to applying the brakes. This is known as engine braking.

questions.question: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, how many are caused by the driver failing to properly yield the right-of-way to the rider?
questions.answerA: About 10 percent
questions.answerB: About 25 percent
questions.answerC: Over 50 percent
questions.answerD: About 90 percent
questions.explanation: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, more than half are caused by the driver failing to properly yield right-of-way to the rider.

questions.question: If road conditions require a longer stopping distance than normal, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your usual following distance.
questions.answerB: Increase your usual following distance.
questions.answerC: Travel on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Ask someone else to operate your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a minimum three-second following distance.

questions.question: Brightly-colored helmets:
questions.answerA: May make it easier for the wearer to be seen.
questions.answerB: Can be distracting.
questions.answerC: Don’t help to improve a rider's visibility.
questions.answerD: Are not permitted.
questions.explanation: Choosing a brightly-colored helmet is recommended. Not only will the helmet protect you in the case of a crash, but the bright color of the helmet will help other road users see you.

questions.question: When applying the front brake, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the lever by squeezing firmly and progressively.
questions.answerB: Grab at the brake with only two fingers.
questions.answerC: Press down on the brake lever with your foot.
questions.answerD: Stomp on the brake lever.
questions.explanation: To apply the front brake, firmly and smoothly squeeze the brake lever with all four fingers, applying progressively more force.

questions.question: Keep an expanded cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you:
questions.answerA: When conditions will make stopping more difficult than usual.
questions.answerB: When you want to look at the scenery.
questions.answerC: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.answerD: To prevent the driver in front of you from knowing you are there.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: Without a helmet, a motorcycle rider is ________ more likely to suffer a critical head injury in a crash.
questions.answerA: Three times
questions.answerB: Four times
questions.answerC: Five times
questions.answerD: Six times
questions.explanation: Without a helmet, a rider is five times more likely to sustain a critical head injury in a crash.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers see you, especially if they make eye contact.
questions.answerB: Never assume other drivers see you.
questions.answerC: Stay focused on moving through the intersection.
questions.answerD: Speed up to make others notice you.
questions.explanation: Never assume that other drivers see you, even if they make eye contact with you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist and still fail to notice them. Always reduce your speed when approaching an intersection.

questions.question: When preparing to pass a vehicle on the left, it is important to ride on the left side of your lane because:
questions.answerA: The right side could be slippery.
questions.answerB: It will give you the best chance of spotting hazards in the next lane.
questions.answerC: People don’t usually expect to be passed on their left.
questions.answerD: It will place you in the rearview mirror of the car in front of you.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This lane position will increase your line of sight and make your more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Motorcycles:
questions.answerA: Do not have blind spots because of their small size.
questions.answerB: Have blind spots, but they are so small they should not cause concern.
questions.answerC: Have blind spots that should be routinely checked.
questions.answerD: Are too small to have blind spots.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head to check your blind spot before changing lanes. Head checks should be a regular part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger in a sidecar, you should:
questions.answerA: Begin slowing sooner than usual.
questions.answerB: Begin slowing later than usual.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes more firmly than usual to stop quickly.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes more softly than usual to keep from overworking them.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a passenger in a sidecar will affect the handling of your motorcycle. Expect your motorcycle to require extra space to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: When riding under ideal conditions, you should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerA: One second.
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least two seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: Taking corners too fast:
questions.answerA: Can cause the rider to go into another lane.
questions.answerB: Is better than going too slowly.
questions.answerC: Often causes the rider to stay in their lane.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable because motorcycles are smaller than other types of vehicles.
questions.explanation: Taking a corner too fast may cause you to cross into another lane or go off the road. Be sure to decelerate before beginning to take a turn or curve.

questions.question: How can you regain control if your rear tire locks up?
questions.answerA: Release the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Continue using the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Swerve the bike in the direction with the fewest hazards.
questions.answerD: With the brake engaged, try to accelerate.
questions.explanation: To regain control of a locked rear wheel, the brake must be released. However, if you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped.

questions.question: When looking for a protective jacket or pair of pants, you should look for:
questions.answerA: Items made of leather.
questions.answerB: Items made of polyester.
questions.answerC: Items made of light materials.
questions.answerD: Items that are darkly-colored.
questions.explanation: It is safest to wear long pants and a jacket to fully cover your arms and legs while riding. Clothing made of leather can provide the highest level of protection.

questions.question: Where is the gearshift lever located?
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handgrip
questions.answerD: On the right handgrip
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated with the left foot.

questions.question: The single most important thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to:
questions.answerA: Wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.
questions.answerB: Wear shorts.
questions.answerC: Wear sneakers.
questions.answerD: Wear goggles.
questions.explanation: The single most effective action you can take to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Always pick one part of the lane to occupy and never leave that part of the lane.
questions.answerB: Vary your lane position as conditions warrant.
questions.answerC: Only ride in the center of the lane so other vehicles can see you more easily.
questions.answerD: Ride in a zigzag pattern so other drivers notice you.
questions.explanation: There is no one lane position that is always best, nor one that should always be avoided. Change your lane position as necessary based on changing road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: If the throttle is stuck, you should:
questions.answerA: Jump off the motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Twist the throttle back and forth several times.
questions.answerD: Not try to twist the throttle.
questions.explanation: If your throttle becomes stuck, try twisting it back and forth several times. If this does not free your throttle, immediately operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch at the same time.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, clothing:
questions.answerA: Should be loose enough to flap in the wind.
questions.answerB: Should not cover your arms or legs completely.
questions.answerC: Should not include a jacket if the weather is warm.
questions.answerD: Can provide protection in the event of a crash.
questions.explanation: The right clothing can provide vital protection if you are involved in a collision. Always wear a jacket and pants that fully cover your arms and legs, even in warm weather. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but should also be loose enough that your movement is not restricted.

questions.question: When riding at night, how should your following distance compare to your following distance during the day?
questions.answerA: You should allow a longer following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerB: You should allow a shorter following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerC: You should always maintain the same following distance regardless of the time of day.
questions.answerD: Following distance really doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: Distances are difficult to judge in the dark because visual cues (like shadows and light contrasts) can be missing or distorted. You should allow a longer following distance when riding at night than you do when riding during the day.

questions.question: When checking tires before a ride, you should look at all of the following except:
questions.answerA: Air pressure
questions.answerB: General wear
questions.answerC: General tread
questions.answerD: Shininess
questions.explanation: Before each ride, you should check the air pressure, tread, and general wear of your tires.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Happen at night.
questions.answerC: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have operated the involved motorcycle for less than six months.
questions.explanation: More than half of all motorcycle crashes involve riders with less than six months of experience on the motorcycle being used.

questions.question: The proper body position on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows you to sit far enough forward that your arms will be slightly bent when holding the handle grips.
questions.answerB: Allows you to sit as far back as possible and have to stretch when trying to reach the handle grips.
questions.answerC: Makes you lean over the bike, requiring your arms to hold you up.
questions.answerD: Allows for your knees to be kept far from the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should sit far enough forward that your arms will be slightly bent when holding the handle grips. This will permit you to easily and comfortably reach and operate the controls.

questions.question: A proper lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Allow you to set up for turns.
questions.answerB: Allow an escape route.
questions.answerC: Allow you to avoid wind blasts from other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Allow you to be in another vehicle’s blind spot.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: Always look through a turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head to look, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Which of the following does not need to be checked regularly?
questions.answerA: The brakes
questions.answerB: The fasteners
questions.answerC: The tires
questions.answerD: The paint
questions.explanation: Before every ride, you should check your motorcycle's tires, controls, chains, sprockets, shock absorbers, fasteners, and brakes. A small mechanical issue on a motorcycle can be extremely dangerous in traffic.

questions.question: When a vehicle attempts to pass you from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Move to the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Move to the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move to the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about which portion of the lane you are using.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of your lane. Being too close to the passing vehicle increases the risk of a collision.

questions.question: Which of the following will help you ride safely on slippery surfaces?
questions.answerA: Using only the front brake
questions.answerB: Using both brakes
questions.answerC: Using the center lane
questions.answerD: Maintaining or increasing your speed
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, reduce your speed, brake using both brakes, and avoid sudden moves. Avoid the center of the lane and instead follow tire tracks left by cars. Always keep an eye out for hazards that may make a road surface especially slippery, such as oil spots and loose gravel.

questions.question: For the best protection, jackets and pants:
questions.answerA: Should cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Should be loose and flap in the wind while you are riding.
questions.answerC: Should only partially cover your arms and legs.
questions.answerD: Should be made of wool.
questions.explanation: To provide adequate protection when riding, jackets and pants should cover your arms and legs completely. Your clothing should fit snugly but be loose enough to let you move freely. Leather or newer kinds of synthetic materials provide the best protection in the case of an accident.

questions.question: Your motorcycle’s brake light is:
questions.answerA: More noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerB: Less noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerC: Less important than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerD: More easily seen than a car’s brake lights.
questions.explanation: The brake light of a motorcycle is usually not as noticeable as the brake lights of a car. Flashing your brake light before slowing or stopping can help other drivers notice that you are about to brake.

questions.question: When passing parked cars, which part of the lane should you usually use?
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane
questions.answerD: Either the left or right portion of the lane
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, it is often safest to ride in the left portion of your lane. Riding in the left portion will keep you farthest from any opening car doors, people stepping out from between cars, and cars pulling out of parking spaces.

questions.question: Maximum straight-line braking is done by:
questions.answerA: Using only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Using only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Using both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel.
questions.answerD: Using both the front and rear brakes while locking the rear wheel.
questions.explanation: On a straightaway, you can stop in the shortest distance by using both brakes. Try to avoid locking either brake.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, which portion of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerA: The left portion
questions.answerB: The center portion
questions.answerC: The right portion
questions.answerD: The shoulder
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should ride in the left portion of the lane to increase your line of sight and make yourself more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Which of the following is a poor reason to sound your horn?
questions.answerA: A driver in the lane next to you is too close to the vehicle ahead of them.
questions.answerB: A parked car has a person in the driver’s seat.
questions.answerC: You want people to look at your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: You are passing someone who is in the street.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to sound your horn before riding past a vehicle or pedestrian that may move into your lane. If you see a driver in an adjacent lane driving too closely to the vehicle ahead of them, you may assume that they want to pass and may cut in front of you to do so. If you see a person in the driver's seat of a parked car, or if you see a pedestrian or bicyclist in the street, it is a good idea to sound your horn as you pass.

questions.question: How does the stopping distance for motorcycles compare to the stopping distance for cars?
questions.answerA: Cars need much longer to stop.
questions.answerB: Cars need a little longer to stop.
questions.answerC: Motorcycles need longer to stop.
questions.answerD: Both motorcycles and cars take about the same amount of time to stop.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, the stopping distances for motorcycles is nearly the same as it is for cars. However, slippery pavement makes quick stops especially difficult for motorcycle operators.

questions.question: To provide the best protection to the wearer, boots or shoes should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Have long laces that are not tucked in.
questions.answerC: Cover the ankle and provide support.
questions.answerD: Have tall heels.
questions.explanation: For riding, choose boots or heavy shoes that are tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Heels should be low so that they won't catch on rough surfaces. Tuck in long laces so that they don't catch on the motorcycle's moving parts.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerA: Slow or stop
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: It is important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerA: You are tired while riding.
questions.answerB: You will be slowing where other drivers won't expect it.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals are not working.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle brake lights are more difficult to see than the brake lights of larger vehicles, so flashing your brake light may help other drivers to notice it. You should flash you brake light before slowing down where other drivers may not expect you to slow down, such as in the middle of a block or when approaching an alley.

questions.question: A major effect of alcohol consumption is:
questions.answerA: Heightened riding abilities.
questions.answerB: The slowing down of bodily functions.
questions.answerC: Increasing nervousness.
questions.answerD: Increasing alertness.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant. It slows down and impairs bodily functions, both physical and mental.

questions.question: Passing and being passed when riding a motorcycle is not much different than when driving a car. However:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle's visibility is more critical than that of a car.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle's visibility is not as important as that of a car.
questions.answerC: Passing should be done on the shoulder instead of on the main roadway.
questions.answerD: It is critical to make eye contact with the other driver when riding a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: While the basic techniques for safely passing and being passed are the same as when driving a car, visibility is more critical when riding a motorcycle. The smaller size of a motorcycle makes it easier for you to disappear into another vehicle's blind spot, or for the driver to fail to notice you even if they are able to see you.

questions.question: A shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Can protect a rider's face in a crash.
questions.answerB: Is only useful in protecting riders from dirt.
questions.answerC: Does not offer as much protection as goggles.
questions.answerD: Should not be used with a helmet.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can provide protection for your entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A face shield also provides routine protection from dirt, dust, insects, rain, and pebbles.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane often contains an oily strip. This strip:
questions.answerA: Is not safe for motorcyclists at any time.
questions.answerB: Is usually safe for motorcyclists, unless it is raining.
questions.answerC: Should always be avoided since other parts of the lane do not have the oily strip.
questions.answerD: Adds to traction for most motorcycle tires.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of a traffic lane. Unless the road is wet, this area will generally still provide enough traction for motorcyclists to ride safely. Because the strip is usually no more than two feet wide, it is often possible to ride to one side of the strip and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a slippery surface?
questions.answerA: A gravel road
questions.answerB: A patch of leaves
questions.answerC: An ice patch
questions.answerD: Dry concrete
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: The front brake supplies approximately how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerA: About 25 percent
questions.answerB: About 50 percent
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: About 95 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. The front brake supplies at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: When it is raining, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull off to the side of the road until the rain stops.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: Wet pavement is especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Deposits of oil left by cars will not yet have washed off the roadway. If it is raining, it is safest to ride in the tire tracks left by cars. The left tire track will often be your best choice, although this may vary.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Avoid sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Brake quickly.
questions.explanation: To safely ride on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed, avoid making sudden movements, and use both brakes if you need to brake.

questions.question: Most crashes happen:
questions.answerA: Far from home.
questions.answerB: On short trips.
questions.answerC: On long rides.
questions.answerD: Several hours into the ride.
questions.explanation: Most crashes happen on trips that are shorter than five miles, just a few minutes after the rider starts out.

questions.question: When passing parked vehicles, motorcycle riders should be especially cautious of:
questions.answerA: Motorists looking for a place to park.
questions.answerB: Cars leaving their parking spaces.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Noise.
questions.explanation: When passing parked vehicles, use caution. You may encounter vehicles pulling away from the curb or leaving parking spaces.

questions.question: When riding near stopped or slow-moving cars, a motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and wait until traffic begins to move.
questions.answerB: Ride on the shoulder to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Weave between the cars to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Not weave between the cars.
questions.explanation: Riding between slowed or parked cars can leave you vulnerable to unexpected hazards, such as opening car doors or cars suddenly pulling into traffic. If a hazard arises, you will not have room to safely maneuver. Never travel on the shoulder of a road because other drivers will never expect you to be there.

questions.question: On a motorcycle, a horn:
questions.answerA: Is useless.
questions.answerB: Usually cannot be heard by others.
questions.answerC: Can be used to get someone’s attention quickly.
questions.answerD: Should not be used.
questions.explanation: Your horn can be a useful tool if you need to get someone's attention quickly. However, because a motorcycle's horn is not as loud as a car's, other drivers may not notice that you are sounding your horn. You should never rely only on your horn to deal with a hazard.

questions.question: If you cannot avoid a slippery road, you should:
questions.answerA: Lean into the slippery section to maintain your balance.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed to improve traction.
questions.answerC: Not worry about the road conditions.
questions.answerD: Keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as needed.
questions.explanation: It is best to entirely avoid slippery stretches of road. However, if there is no way to avoid such an area, keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as possible.

questions.question: The gearshift lever is operated by:
questions.answerA: Your right hand.
questions.answerB: Your right foot.
questions.answerC: Your left hand.
questions.answerD: Your left foot.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever of a motorcycle is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the rider's left foot.

questions.question: To increase your line of sight when preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Try to stand up on your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This will increase your line of sight and make you more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a slippery surface?
questions.answerA: A dirt or gravel road
questions.answerB: A strip of oil in the center of a lane
questions.answerC: Mud on pavement
questions.answerD: Dry pavement
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; oily areas; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle, you should ride in the left portion of your lane because:
questions.answerA: It increases your line of sight.
questions.answerB: It decreases your line of sight.
questions.answerC: It makes it difficult to see beyond the vehicle.
questions.answerD: It allows the other driver to speed up.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane, both to increase your line of sight and to make yourself more visible to drivers already in the passing lane.

questions.question: The shortest and safest stops are accomplished:
questions.answerA: By using only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: By using only the front brake.
questions.answerC: By allowing the front tire to lock up.
questions.answerD: By using both the front and rear brakes.
questions.explanation: The shortest and safest stops are achieved by using both the front and rear brakes in a smooth and progressive manner, without skidding either tire.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to blend into traffic and not be noticed by other drivers.
questions.answerB: Not use turn signals unless you are traveling at night.
questions.answerC: Use your turn signals when changing lanes and making turns.
questions.answerD: Ride closely to the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, ensure that you are visible to others on the road. Communicate your intentions through your turn signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain an adequate space cushion, scan your path of travel 12 seconds ahead of your vehicle, and be prepared to act if any hazards arise.

questions.question: Proper clothing for riding offers all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Comfort.
questions.answerB: Protection in a collision.
questions.answerC: Protection from the cold.
questions.answerD: Discomfort.
questions.explanation: Proper clothing for riding can help protect you from injury in the event of a collision. It can also protect against routine hazards and discomforts, such as hot or cold weather.

questions.question: When approaching railroad tracks that cross your lane at an angle, it is usually:
questions.answerA: Safest to ride straight within your lane to cross the tracks.
questions.answerB: Dangerous to ride straight within your lane to cross the tracks.
questions.answerC: Not safe to cross tracks on a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Safest to cross the tracks by riding on the shoulder of the road.
questions.explanation: When approaching railroad tracks that cross your lane at an angle, it is best to simply cross the tracks while riding straight within your lane. Turning to cross the tracks at a 90-degree angle could be dangerous because you could end up crossing into another lane of traffic.

questions.question: One way to tell if your rear tire has gone flat while riding is if:
questions.answerA: There is a hissing noise coming from the rear of the bike.
questions.answerB: The back end is jerking from side to side.
questions.answerC: You are unable to accelerate.
questions.answerD: The rear brake does not work.
questions.explanation: If your rear tire fails, the back of your motorcycle will likely jerk from side to side. It is rare for motorcyclists to actually hear a tire fail.

questions.question: A proper lane position can help you do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Avoid other drivers' blindspots.
questions.answerB: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Go faster.
questions.answerD: Set up for turns.
questions.explanation: Your lane position affects a number of factors that are important to your safety on the road. Among other things, your position should help you increase your ability to see and be seen, avoid other drivers' blind spots, and set you up for any turns you plan to make.

questions.question: Which of the following types of footwear is best for a motorcycle operator?
questions.answerA: Sturdy boots
questions.answerB: Tennis shoes
questions.answerC: Shoes with loose laces
questions.answerD: Sandals
questions.explanation: Sturdy boots or shoes that are high enough to support the ankles can provide the best protection for motorcyclists. Laced up boots are best, but high-top boots or heavy shoes are fine. If a motorcyclist wears shoes that have long laces, they should be sure to securely tuck the laces away before riding.

questions.question: Riding at night is usually:
questions.answerA: Easier than riding during the day because you can more easily see the lights of other vehicles.
questions.answerB: More difficult than riding during the day because it is harder to see.
questions.answerC: Not allowed on highways.
questions.answerD: Less distracting than riding during the day.
questions.explanation: Riding safely at night is challenging because it is harder to see and be seen than it is during the day. The absence of normal shadows and light contrasts makes it harder to judge distances.

questions.question: When both braking and swerving must be done to avoid an unexpected hazard, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Perform one action, then the other.
questions.answerB: Perform both actions at the same time and apply extra braking pressure.
questions.answerC: Perform both actions at the same time, but mainly focus on swerving.
questions.answerD: Not perform either action.
questions.explanation: Because you need adequate traction to swerve safely, you should not brake and swerve at the same time. Instead, if you approach a hazard that requires you to brake and swerve, you should perform one action and then the other.

questions.question: Riding alongside another rider:
questions.answerA: Allows you to maximize the surface of the road.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerC: Allows you to communicate with one another.
questions.answerD: Makes it easier for other motorists to pass.
questions.explanation: You should not ride alongside another motorcyclist because doing so will limit both of your possible routes of escape if you encounter a hazard.

questions.question: To help other drivers see you, you should wear:
questions.answerA: Darkly-colored clothes.
questions.answerB: Brightly-colored clothes.
questions.answerC: Lights.
questions.answerD: A black jacket.
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing will help you to be seen by other road users. Wear clothes that increase your visibility both during the day and at night.

questions.question: The best source of information for your motorcycle is:
questions.answerA: The owner’s manual.
questions.answerB: A general book about motorcycles.
questions.answerC: Someone who has a different type of motorcycle.
questions.answerD: A television show about motorcycle riding.
questions.explanation: To be sure you are familiar with the specific type of motorcycle that you are planning to ride, read the owner's manual before riding it for the first time. This is particularly important if you are riding a borrowed motorcycle.

questions.question: If your front tire goes flat while you are riding:
questions.answerA: The steering will feel heavy.
questions.answerB: The steering will feel loose.
questions.answerC: There will be no change in the steering.
questions.answerD: The ride will feel too smooth.
questions.explanation: If the front tire of a motorcycle fails, it will cause the steering to feel heavy. If your steering feels heavy, immediately exit the road and inspect your tires.

questions.question: Before mounting the motorcycle, your pre-ride inspection should include all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A tire check.
questions.answerB: A taillight test.
questions.answerC: A headlight test.
questions.answerD: A paint check.
questions.explanation: A pre-ride inspection should include checks of the tires, oil and fluids, lights, signals, clutch, throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn. Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride.

questions.question: A DOT-approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Restricts the wearer's vision to the sides.
questions.answerB: Can greatly reduce the severity of a head injury.
questions.answerC: Is usually uncomfortable.
questions.answerD: Makes it more difficult for the wearer to control their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet while riding greatly improves your chances of avoiding serious injury to your head or neck in the case of a crash. A DOT-approved helmet will not restrict your vision to the sides.

questions.question: It is difficult for other motorists to see motorcycles at night. To make up for that, a motorcycle rider should:
questions.answerA: Reduce their speed when riding at night.
questions.answerB: Sound their horn repeatedly when riding at night.
questions.answerC: Not ride at night.
questions.answerD: Stay directly in front of another vehicle to be seen in their headlights when riding at night.
questions.explanation: Strategies for safely riding at night include reducing your speed, increasing your following distance, using the lights of the car ahead to help see farther down the road, using your high beam headlight (unless following or meeting another vehicle), and being flexible about your lane position.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Involve riders who have operated their motorcycles for less than six months.
questions.answerB: Are caused by faulty ignition systems.
questions.answerC: Occur because of distractions caused by passengers.
questions.answerD: Happen at night.
questions.explanation: Always be very careful when riding a motorcycle that is new to you. In most motorcycle crashes, the operator had less than six months of experience on the bike that they were riding.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors, you should focus on:
questions.answerA: The road behind and to the side of your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Your arms.
questions.answerC: The road in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: The side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you. When properly adjusted, a mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder, but it’s the road behind you and to the side of you that is most important.

questions.question: Can clothing help prevent injuries in the event of a crash?
questions.answerA: No, clothing is not really for protection.
questions.answerB: No, clothing is more of a personal choice.
questions.answerC: Yes, but only if garments are very loose and flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Yes, if pants and a jacket cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.explanation: Appropriate clothing can reduce the risk of injury in a crash. Choose a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs, are made of sturdy material, and are snug enough that they do not flap in the wind.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerA: On short trips.
questions.answerB: On long trips.
questions.answerC: After at least an hour of riding.
questions.answerD: After more than 8 hours of riding.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on trips shorter than five miles, just a few minutes after the rider starts out.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Get as close as possible to the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerD: Not signal your intentions, as that may distract the driver you are passing.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. Signal your intentions and check for traffic. Pass when it is safe to do so, then signal and return to your original lane when traffic allows.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Help you avoid road hazards.
questions.answerB: Help you avoid other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerC: Help you avoid being seen by other drivers.
questions.answerD: Increase your ability to be seen by others.
questions.explanation: A well-chosen lane position should increase your ability to see and be seen and keep you out of other drivers' blind spots. It should help you avoid surface hazards, protect your lane from other drivers, communicate your intentions to others, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and offer you an escape route from any hazards that may arise.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerA: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because they will distract you.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided since other drivers will see you easily.
questions.answerD: Are only recommended in bad weather.
questions.explanation: For your safety, it is important to be aware of what's behind you. Frequent mirror checks should be a part of your normal searching routine.

questions.question: A simple way to make your motorcycle easier to see is to:
questions.answerA: Ride with a large flag attached to its frame.
questions.answerB: Ride with the headlight turned on.
questions.answerC: Wave at other drivers.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder whenever possible.
questions.explanation: You can make yourself easier to see by wearing brightly-colored, reflective clothing. Ride with your headlight on at all times and use your turn signals and brake light appropriately.

questions.question: Riding gloves should:
questions.answerA: Not be worn because they will make your hands too hot.
questions.answerB: Be worn to provide a better grip on the handgrips.
questions.answerC: Not be worn because they will make it more difficult to work the controls.
questions.answerD: Be worn only on cooler days.
questions.explanation: Gloves made of leather, or another durable material, should be worn when riding. They will provide you with an improved grip on the handgrips, as well as help protect your hands in the event of a crash.

questions.question: For the best protection, riding gloves should be made of:
questions.answerA: Leather.
questions.answerB: Wool.
questions.answerC: Polyester.
questions.answerD: Silk.
questions.explanation: Gloves should be made of leather or another durable material to provide proper protection for the wearer.

questions.question: Before carrying a passenger in traffic for the first time, you should:
questions.answerA: Read books about carrying passengers.
questions.answerB: Practice riding on an empty road.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights so others can see you.
questions.answerD: Practice riding on the shoulder of a road.
questions.explanation: Before transporting a passenger or heavy load in traffic for the first time, practice riding on a quiet road to get used to how your motorcycle handles differently with the additional weight.

questions.question: If drinking alcohol, you should:
questions.answerA: Decide if you are still fit to ride based on how you feel after you finish drinking.
questions.answerB: Set a limit beforehand so you can still safely ride.
questions.answerC: Not ride.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about your riding abilities if you feel fine.
questions.explanation: The surest way to avoid the risks of riding under the influence of alcohol is to not ride after you have been drinking. Any amount of alcohol can impair your abilities.

questions.question: Approved helmets:
questions.answerA: Can limit the view of the motorcycle operator.
questions.answerB: Allow the motorcycle operator to see as far to the sides as necessary.
questions.answerC: Are dangerous to wear.
questions.answerD: Do not have to be worn if the motorcycle operator thinks their view would be limited.
questions.explanation: While some people worry that wearing a helmet may dangerously limit their field of vision, this is not the case. Any approved helmet will let the operator see as far to the sides as is needed for safe riding.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerA: Are unimportant.
questions.answerB: Should only be done on long trips.
questions.answerC: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerD: Are not helpful since you can’t do anything about what is behind you.
questions.explanation: Frequent mirror checks should be part of your normal searching routine. Additionally, make a special point of using your mirrors before changing lanes, when stopping at an intersection, and before slowing down.

questions.question: Riding at night:
questions.answerA: Is discouraged.
questions.answerB: Is made safer by wearing reflective clothing.
questions.answerC: Is not safe because other drivers cannot see your turn signals.
questions.answerD: Should only be done in the city.
questions.explanation: You should wear reflective materials when riding at night to make yourself more visible to other road users.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerA: Always
questions.answerB: Usually
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists will seldom hear their tire go flat. Tire failure is more commonly indicated by a sudden change in handling.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are designed to:
questions.answerA: Prevent skidding and wheel lock-up.
questions.answerB: Prevent brakes from activating if the roadway is dry.
questions.answerC: Apply brakes automatically.
questions.answerD: Warn you when your brake pad needs replacing.
questions.explanation: Some motorcycles are equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS). ABS is designed to prevent skidding and wheel lock-up when motorcyclists are stopping in straight-line, panic situations. ABS operates when maximum pressure is applied to both the front and rear brake controls. If electronic sensors detect the possibility of a wheel lock, brake hydraulic pressure is released then re-applied to maintain maximum braking effectiveness.

questions.question: What does this signal mean?
questions.answerA: Rest stop
questions.answerB: High beams on
questions.answerC: Turn right
questions.answerD: Hazard
questions.explanation: Signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. When the lead rider's right leg is extended, it means there is a hazard in the roadway on their right side.

questions.question: If your front wheel begins to skid, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the front brake engaged and ride out the skid.
questions.answerB: Keep the front brake engaged and release the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Immediately release and re-engage the front brake.
questions.answerD: Release the front brake and increase the pressure on the rear brake.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks while braking, you should release the front brake immediately and completely before re-applying it smoothly.

questions.question: If you must swerve, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerB: Turn your handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: When approaching an uneven surface, such as a bump or pothole, you should rise slightly off of your seat:
questions.answerA: So you can jump off the motorcycle if you need to.
questions.answerB: So your legs can absorb the shock.
questions.answerC: So other drivers can see you better.
questions.answerD: So you can get a better view of the uneven surface.
questions.explanation: When riding over an uneven surface, rising off of your seat will allow your joints to absorb some of the force of impact. This will make it less likely that the impact of the surface will throw you off of the motorcycle.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-ride check, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The brakes make a loud squeaking noise.
questions.answerB: The brakes cause some friction with the steering.
questions.answerC: Each brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Only the rear brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Check your brake levers individually before every ride. Make sure each one feels firm and holds the motorcycle when the brake is fully applied.

questions.question: A properly-fitted motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows the rider to touch the ground with their feet while seated.
questions.answerB: Has a seat even with the rider's waist.
questions.answerC: Has a seat that is 10 inches above the rider's waist.
questions.answerD: Has a seat that is 10 inches below the rider's waist.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle fits you properly, your feet should be able to reach the ground while you are seated. When riding your motorcycle, keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: Impairment from drinking alcohol occurs:
questions.answerA: Well below the legal limit.
questions.answerB: Once reaching the legal limit.
questions.answerC: Just above the legal limit.
questions.answerD: Well above the legal limit.
questions.explanation: It is never safe to operate a motorcycle after consuming any amount of alcohol. Impairment of the skills needed to safely ride begins well below the legal limit.

questions.question: Most crashes occur in broad daylight. To be more visible, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear brightly-colored clothing.
questions.answerB: Wear darkly-clothing.
questions.answerC: Ride without your headlight.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: Because most crashes happen in broad daylight, you should always wear brightly-colored clothing while riding, even during the day.

questions.question: In general, riders should:
questions.answerA: Pick one lane position and always use it.
questions.answerB: Change lane positions frequently to prevent monotony.
questions.answerC: Choose a lane position that maximizes their space cushion.
questions.answerD: Never use the center lane position.
questions.explanation: Because road and traffic conditions are always changing, the safest lane position is also always changing. Choose the position that will maximize your space cushion and allow other drivers to see you most easily.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride faster than usual.
questions.answerB: Rider more slowly than usual.
questions.answerC: Start slowing later than usual.
questions.answerD: Try to squeeze into smaller gaps in traffic.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a passenger will affect the handling of your motorcycle. Expect your motorcycle to accelerate more slowly than usual, turn more slowly than usual, and require extra space to come to a complete stop. Ride more slowly, start slowing sooner when approaching a stop, open up a larger space cushion, and wait for larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging into traffic.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, motorcycle riders should turn their heads to look over their shoulders because:
questions.answerA: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like other vehicles.
questions.answerB: They can catch the attention of other drivers by turning their heads.
questions.answerC: Mirrors are not really helpful.
questions.answerD: They should try to make eye contact with surrounding drivers.
questions.explanation: Like any other vehicle, a motorcycle has blind spots that cannot be seen by a rider using their mirrors. A motorcyclist should always turn their head to check for vehicles or other hazards in their blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: Where is the rear brake pedal usually located?
questions.answerA: On the left handgrip
questions.answerB: On the right handgrip
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The rear brake of a motorcycle is usually controlled by a pedal near the right footrest.

questions.question: Low-speed crashes:
questions.answerA: Can be fatal.
questions.answerB: Are never serious.
questions.answerC: Rarely cause injuries.
questions.answerD: Happen frequently, so there is no need to worry about them.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur at speeds lower than 30 miles per hour. Even low-speed crashes can be fatal.

questions.question: A motorcycle “fits” you if:
questions.answerA: You are able to touch your feet to the ground while seated.
questions.answerB: You are able to reach the controls by stretching.
questions.answerC: The handlebars go over your head.
questions.answerD: Your feet are unable to rest on the foot pegs.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle fits you properly if your feet can reach the ground while you are seated on the motorcycle. It should be easy for you to reach and operate the controls.

questions.question: A child passenger:
questions.answerA: Should be placed in front of the operator.
questions.answerB: Should be placed behind the operator.
questions.answerC: Does not have to be able to reach the footrests.
questions.answerD: Should hold onto the motorcycle frame.
questions.explanation: A child passenger on a motorcycle should always ride immediately behind the operator. A child sitting in front may be unable to balance properly and could interfere with the operator's use of the controls.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good way for a rider to increase their visibility?
questions.answerA: Wearing proper clothing
questions.answerB: Using their headlight at all times
questions.answerC: Using their turn signals
questions.answerD: Waving at other drivers
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to other road users, you should wear brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials, use your headlight at all times, and use your signals and brake light properly.

questions.question: A thorough check of your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Is useless unless done by a mechanic.
questions.answerB: Should not be done before a ride.
questions.answerC: Should be done only after a ride.
questions.answerD: Can help you identify any mechanical defects or equipment failures.
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you thoroughly check your motorcycle before every ride. Doing this can help you identify mechanical defects or equipment failures that could endanger you.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Should only be used when you need to stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Should be used only under slippery conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not as effective as the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Is safe to use, if used properly.
questions.explanation: Always use both brakes any time you slow or stop. It is safe to use the front brake, which is more powerful than the rear brake, as long as you use it properly.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerA: Just behind the leader.
questions.answerB: In front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the tail end of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders to keep an eye on them without forcing the inexperienced rider to lead the group.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Only ride in the afternoon.
questions.answerB: Follow the vehicle in front of you as closely as possible.
questions.answerC: Not look ahead and focus only on your controls.
questions.answerD: Communicate your intentions to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: If carrying a load in a sidecar, the motorcycle's stopping distance:
questions.answerA: May be increased.
questions.answerB: May be decreased.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern.
questions.answerD: Will be similar to the stopping distance of a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Because adding a load to a motorcycle increases its weight, the vehicle's inertia may increase, causing its stopping distance to increase. Begin slowing and stopping earlier when riding a motorcycle with a load or passenger in its sidecar.

questions.question: To lean the motorcycle for a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Apply the front brake.
questions.answerD: Apply the rear brake.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle needs to lean in order to turn. To make this happen, press on the handgrip in the direction you want to turn.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to weave while you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, you should:
questions.answerA: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.answerB: Tighten your hold on the handle grips and increase your speed to get past the hazard.
questions.answerC: Travel in a zigzag motion.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder instead of on the grooves.
questions.explanation: The weaving motion that occurs when a motorcycle rides over rain grooves or bridge gratings is generally not dangerous. If you experience weaving when riding over one of these surfaces, simply relax and proceed straight across the grooves or gratings at a steady speed. Trying to compensate for the weaving motion by zigzagging is more dangerous than riding straight.

questions.question: To get the best protection, be sure that your helmet:
questions.answerA: Meets Department of Transportation guidelines.
questions.answerB: Looks sturdy.
questions.answerC: Is inexpensive.
questions.answerD: Is in your favorite color.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: If you accidentally lock your rear wheel while braking on a good traction surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep it locked until you come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake, then quickly re-apply it.
questions.answerD: Release the rear brake and down shift.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, keep it locked until you have completely stopped. Even with a locked rear wheel, you should still be able to control your motorcycle if it is upright and traveling in a straight line.

questions.question: To be effective, a face shield should not:
questions.answerA: Be free of scratches.
questions.answerB: Allow clear views to both sides.
questions.answerC: Be airtight.
questions.answerD: Fasten securely.
questions.explanation: An effective face shield should be free of scratches, be resistant to penetration, allow clear views to both sides, fasten securely, permit air to pass through, and provide enough space for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath.
